title: The social construction of the socialist past in eastern Germany
abstractText:
The ‘post-socialist transition’ has changed the very terms of reference for evaluating the socialist past and the post-socialist present in crucial ways leading to highly flexible cultural reflections intertwined with strong moral positioning.

‘The social construction of the socialist past’ will be studied in two settings which play a key part in shaping this reflection: a newspaper editorial office, and a state government (Landesregierung) in eastern Germany. In eastern Germany there is a multiplicity of communal memories of the former German Democratic Republic ranging from nostalgic sentiments to government-sponsored critical examinations of the ‘totalitarian state’, all of which are contentious in the public.

The research consists of ethnographic study in each setting including participant observation and interviews to enquire into the day-to-day management of ‘re-working the past’ and the tacit knowledge underpinning it. The interviews will explore individual reflections and value-judgements about past and present. The analysis will highlight differences in interpreting and representing the past between governmental, institutional and individual discourses, resulting contestation and its potential resolution.

Furthermore, the project aims to establish a network of scholars interested in how cultural reflections about the past play out in other postsocialist societies.
